title: Exclusive: Olympic and Paralympic organisers able to bring forward events if typhoons strike during Tokyo Games
text:
Olympic and Paralympic organisers could bring forward competition ahead of their respective opening ceremonies if more destructive weather is forecast in Tokyo next year.

Both Games' official rules prevent any delays in the scheduled closing ceremonies so administrators will instead be reliant on long-term forecasts to avoid any repeats of the storm chaos seen at the Rugby World Cup.

A typhoon is unlikely to hit the Olympics at the end of July and start of August, but the Paralympics, between August 25 and September 6, falls in the middle of storm season.

The International Paralympic Committee has told The Daily Telegraph it has powers to bring forward non-medal events - such as heats or group-stage matches - in the event of unforeseen extreme weather.

A byelaw to Rule 32 in the International Olympic Committee guide also bans any moves by organisers to delay closing ceremonies. "The duration of the competitions of the Olympic Games shall not exceed 16 days unless otherwise approved by the relevant IF and the IOC Executive Board, in which case some competitions and preliminaries may be organised prior to the Opening Ceremony," the rule says.
